fields.name: ReAllocate
fields.org_mission: Enabling cooperative innovation and connecting world class talent with real world problems.

fields.name: miraclefeet
fields.org_mission: miraclefeet is dedicated to providing proper treatment for children born with clubfoot in developing countries. miraclefeet partners with local orthopedic surgeons working in public hospitals to establish and support clubfoot clinics within the existing public health system. miraclefeet believes this is the most effective, efficient and sustainable approach to prevent the significant disability caused by untreated clubfoot around the world.

fields.name: Cordova Community Cold Storage
fields.description:
All of rural Alaska faces the challenge of maintaining a high-quality subsistence food supply. Lacking variety and regular availability, it becomes difficult to train young taste buds and impossible to avoid highly-processed and expensive commercial alternatives. At the same time, cottage industries in Alaska have a problem producing high-quality food products for sale because the processing and packaging equipment are built (and priced!) for larger operations. In Cordova, these barriers mean that fewer than 25 of the 550 Copper River Delta commercial fishermen are direct-marketing their salmon; instead, they sell their entire catch for low prices to canneries or outside cash buyers.

To address these problems, EPC is helping individuals and businesspeople to create a Cordova Community Cold Storage and Cookery (CCCS). We will offer processing tables, a vacuum sealer, a blast freezer, cooler space, and a place to package finished products safely and efficiently. CCCS users will be able to safely dress, process, smoke and preserve subsistence foods including seafoods, shellfish, red meats, and plants and berries. Because the CCCS will be a Department of Environmental Conservation approved facility, small commercial producers will also be able to share its use.

In October 2007, Alaska Federation of Natives chose the CCCS as one of the top four business concepts in the Alaska Marketplace competition. We are developing a business plan and investigating energy saving systems such as solar, wind and tidal power sources to help reduce energy costs, as these represent one of the most significant financial hurdles to such a facility. If CCCS pencils out as expected, additional funding will be needed for final design of the facility, start-up capital, and purchase of equipment. Help us with support for this state-of-the-art subsistence model. Communities all over should have them!

fields.name: ReAllocate
fields.short_desc: World class talent, real world problems
fields.description: Creating meaning through innovation. Connecting meaningful projects with innovators who want to make a difference.

fields.name: Miracle Brace
fields.short_desc: Treating clubfoot one step at a time
fields.description:
Creating an innovative brace to cure children with clubfoot around the world.

Clubfoot is a congenital deformity that results in inwardly rotated feet at the ankles. It is a common disorder which affects one in every 750 babies born, and results in over 200,000 children born with clubfoot every year. Because 80% of cases occur in developing countries, families often do not have access to, or are unable to afford the treatment to correct clubfoot. For affected children, the Miracle Brace is a life-changing piece of technology that allows them to run, play, and live their lives free of handicap.

miraclefeet, a nonprofit dedicated to finding a non-surgical approach to healing clubfoot, approached ReAllocate with a project. miraclefeet's mission was to design an easy-to-produce, low-cost brace; what is now the Miracle Brace, so that children born with clubfoot have the chance to walk. ReAllocate collaborated with Autodesk, Objet, and TechShop SF to provide the resources that met the needs of miraclefeet.

With the help of miraclefeet, ReAllocate worked with orthopedic surgeons and clinicians in Nicaragua to better understand the project's cost and resource parameters and to communicate those parameters with ReAllocate's production partners, Autodesk and Objet.

ReAllocate recruited the help of Billy Wheeler at Autodesk. Using Inventor, Autodesk's 3D CAD software, Billy Wheeler and Dr. Mike North drafted several digital prototypes for the new brace. Bruce Bradshaw with Objet provided 3D printers and printing materials to produce each prototype of the Miracle Brace

As a part of the development process, Dr. North traveled to Nicaragua with miraclefeet to test the prototypes with children and doctors affected by clubfoot.

ReAllocate and miraclefeet's co-patented invention, the Miracle Brace, has created an avalanche of support for miraclefeet; this includes significant financial contributions to miraclefeet, as well as partnerships with Stanford, Clarks Shoes, and a major injection molding company.

Thanks to the collaboration of an amazing team of engineers and partners, miraclefeet using the Miracle Brace is now on its way to making major impact around the world.

fields.name: Create Energy Plan
fields.short_desc: Create a sustainable energy plan for the community cold storage facility in Cordova, Alaska. Use your skills to help subsistence communities
fields.description:
The Eyak Preservation council needs help complete an energy audit for a community cold storage facilty in Cordova. The energy plan will be used to scope and source the materials for a renewable energy system to power the facility.

Eyak is in need of an energy engineer with experience in renewable energy systems to help determine the energy requirements and best solutions for a facility in Cordova Alaska powered 100% by renewable resources

fields.name: Donate Materials
fields.short_desc: Help purchase a cold storage freezer for CCCS. This freezer will help support rural communities and small commercial fisherman in Cordova
fields.description: Help CCCS buy a freezer for their prototype cold storage facility. The facility is going to need to store more than 1,000,000 pounds of Salmon a year. The salmon is both for commercial fisherman to store their catch to sell to market and for members of local community to store their subsistence food for winter stock. Donating money to this opportunity will go directly to the purchase of a large freezer for the facilty in Cordova.

fields.name: Design Product with CAD
fields.short_desc: Lend a hand to treating clubfoot by creating CAD designs of a new brace!
fields.description:
The miraclefeet organization is working on creating a new bracing solution for treating kids with clubfoot. We could use the help of a CAD designer with the ability to rapidly prototype a new bracing solution to lower the cost of treatment for club foot.

Time: 25-50 Hours over 1-3 Months

Skills: CAD Design

Deliverable: The .STL file of the product design

Project Steps: Organization provides design breif to designer.
Designer and organization have a kick off call to discuss the product design
Designer creates and delivers a preliminary design
Designer and Organization discuss the design and decide if a round of revisions is necessary
Designer makes revisions and provides final design

fields.name: Build a web Marketplace
fields.short_desc: Hackers unite! We are building an online marketplace to offer your knowledge and resources to create innovations for good! Join us!
fields.description: Come hack together to create an online marketplace to help projects connect with skilled volunteers to do good. We are building the foundation for a new economy that moves the world away from money towards meaning to improve global quality of life.

fields.name: Build a Prototype
fields.short_desc: Can you help prototype a life saving device for children with clubfoot? Come work on this opportunity to change the lives of children!
fields.description: We have completed the design of our prototype and now we need help brining it into reality! We are looking for an experienced engineer who can bring our CAD models to life!

fields.name: Donate Material List
fields.short_desc: Donate materials to build and test a prototype brace for treating clubfoot. With your support we can cure more than 200k cases of clubfoot!
fields.description: We are working on getting a new brace designed and prototyped. The rapid prototyping process involves 3D printing and we could use help purchasing the materials to complete the prototypes. A materials list and all costs is provided so you know exactly where you money is going to help build a treatment for children with club foot.

fields.name: Donate Travel
fields.short_desc: Our first prototypes are done and we need your help to travel to Nicaragua and work with the local doctors to test the new brace!
fields.description: Help buy a plane ticket for our engineer to visit patients in Nicaragua so he can test our new brace on children we have been working with. We have been working with Dr. Ruiz and he is ready to test our new bracing solution on his patients. Please help complete this important step in the process so we can get real live testing on the product that the ReAllocate community has made possible!

fields.name: Donate a 3D Printer
fields.short_desc: Can you help reduce our prototype costs by granting access to a 3D printer for some rapid prototyping of a brace to treat clubfoot?
fields.description: Our engineers need access to a 3D Printer to create the prototype for the Miracle Brace. Does anyone have access to a 3D printer that we could use for this?

fields.name: Research the Needs
fields.short_desc: Can you help us interview doctors around the world and gather knowledge about the best treatments available for addressing clubfoot?
fields.description: We need help from an engineering expert to interview doctors who are working on treating clubfoot. We need to determine from their experience what needs to be included in a new bracing system

fields.text: "If you're going through hell, keep going." -Churchill

"Rural Alaskans rely on subsistence food for their way of life. This means they harvest, process and store their own food to feed their families and survive the long Alaskan winters. In the Alaskan frontier there is no Walmart, no convenience store and your delivery driver flies an airplane! In partnership with the Eyak Preservation Council and the University of California, Berkeley, ReAllocate is helping to build a community cold storage facility in Cordova, Alaska. This facility is an innovative approach to providing high quality subsistence food processing for rural populations. It will also create new sustainable economic opportunities for commercial fishermen, by opening direct-to-market sales channels, increasing their earning potential and improving existing cottage industries. All of rural Alaska faces the challenge of maintaining a high-quality subsistence food supply. Food processing centers are built to serve large corporate clients and are not suited for the needs of smaller commercial and rural fishers and hunters. This means it's harder for rural families to process and store their food for survival and independant commercial fishermen are forced to sell their catch to large canneries at a fraction of the cost of selling direct-to-market."
"An adventure is not a goal, but rather an experience that had better be shared with your friends" - TR
